awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Design and Study of Chalcogen-Containing Cationic Dyes for Photocatalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of methods to transform molecules into useful materials and products is a key challenge facing chemists. One common transformation is an oxidation reaction, where oxygen is added to or electrons are removed from a molecule. Oxidation reactions often rely on toxic reagents that produce a large amount of waste.  The use of molecular oxygen could reduce both the cost of these reactions and the amount of waste produced. Molecular oxygen is also abundant in air.  Scientists generally do not know how to use atmospheric oxygen to transform molecules into desired products. In this project, Dr. McCormick of Portland State University and Drs. Detty and Cook of the University at Buffalo are investigating dyes that can use energy from light to make desirable molecular transformations with atmospheric oxygen. By understanding how changing the structure of a dye influences its reactivity, it may be possible to control and target these oxidation reactions. Drs. McCormick, Detty, and Cook are dedicated to increasing education in areas of sustainability via the implementation of new courses. They provide research internships to students to increase their awareness of the impact of development on the environment and their role as scientists in creating sustainable solutions.  The curriculum revisions may increase student engagement in issues of sustainability and photochemistry. The modules are disseminated to allow schools across the country to adopt the curriculum, which focuses on on principles of green chemistry, environmental protection, and renewable energy. A more engaged and informed science workforce may be better able to solve current and future problems of sustainability.

Drs. McCormick, Detty, and Cook are supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division to investigate chalcogen-containing dyes as photosensitizers for photocatalytic redox reactions. The use of photo-induced redox catalysis for synthetic transformations is of interest due to its potential for the green production of small molecules at both laboratory and industrial scale. The interchange of the chalcogen atoms (O, S, or Se to Te) in the xanthylium or pyrylium core of the dyes allows control of redox behavior in the dyes, as well as wavelengths of absorption, fluorescence yields and lifetimes, and triplet yields and lifetimes. The chalcogen-containing dyes function as photo-oxidants in that the excited state can accept an electron to give a one-electron oxidation of a substrate. The excited state can also intersystem-cross from singlet to triplet and then interact with ground-state oxygen to generate singlet-oxygen, which can function as a potent oxidant.  This research may result in a decreased reliance on fossil fuels by providing a route to hydrogen peroxide production, decreasing carbon emissions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In 2017 PI McCormick, in collaboration with Profs M. Detty and T. Cook from the State University of New York, University at Buffalo, was awarded an NSF award from the Math and Physical Science Directorate, Division of Chemistry. This reports the work completed at Portland State University, where six graduate students and six undergraduate students have been trained on the project, producing seven peer reviewed publications, and nineteen oral presentations on the work.

The overall goal of the project was to show that tellurium containing dyes can self-sensitize aerobic oxidation reactions. To do this we studied these reactions and how modifications effect the reaction kinetics. Aerobic oxidation reactions are reactions where either an oxygen is incorporated into a product, or electrons are removed. These reactions are typically done using toxic oxidizing reagents. The ideal oxidizing agent is oxygen, since it is readily available in air. However, the electrons in oxygen from the air are arranged in a way that makes it difficult for it to react with most other compounds. But we can use light to change the electronic configuration of the oxygen to produce a reactive oxygen species, singlet oxygen. Since this transformation involves light, we must use a dye molecule to capture that energy.

Results. We have shown that dye molecules containing a tellurium atom in their structure can interact with light and produce singlet oxygen, and react with that singlet oxygen, making them self-sensitizing. The singlet oxygen oxidizes the tellurium atom in the dye from the Te(II) oxidation state to the Te(IV) oxidation state to make a telluroixde. Interestingly, the telluroixde can then be used to oxidize other substrates, regenerating the original Te(II) dye. Thus, the tellurium containing dyes can act as an oxidation relay to absorb light, create singlet oxygen, then react with the singlet oxygen to form the telluroxide that oxidized a target substrate. Since the tellurium containing dye is regenerated, the process is catalytic.

In this project we have shown that the telluroxide can oxidize reactions of 2-aryl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinolines in aza-Henry type reactions, silane oxidation to silanols, and phosphines to phosphine oxides. This is in addition to the oxidation of thiols to disulfides that we had previously demonstrated. Interestingly, these oxidations fall into two classes, oxidase (oxidation without the transfer of oxygen), and oxygenase (oxidation with the transfer of an oxygen atom). This is the first time, to our knowledge, that a single catalyst has demonstrate this dual reactivity. This will have an impact on the field of aerobic oxidation, demonstrating these two different mechanisms are possible for a singlet catalyst. These oxidation reactions not only allow oxygen from the air to be used as the oxidant in these transformations, they also produce hydrogen peroxide as a byproduct of the reaction.

Hydrogen peroxide is an industrially relevant compound, used as an oxidant, disinfectant, and bleaching reagent. Recent interest has grown in using hydrogen peroxide as a fuel in a chemical fuel cell. All of these applications would benefit from a green method to make hydrogen peroxide from oxygen and water. We discovered that hydrogen peroxide is produced in the oxidation step of this reaction, demonstrating a photochemical method of hydrogen peroxide production by oxidizing water and reducing oxygen from air.

During the pursuit of these research goals we have developed methods and tools that have made standard and complicated photochemical methods more routine. Specifically, we have used change in pressure to measure singlet oxygen yields, and actinometry, and have developed a computational model to predict the singlet oxygen yields from new dyes. These methods will be widely applicable to all fields of photochemistry.  

Direct outreach from this project includes work with the Women in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math), which is now the Women and Gender Minorities in STEM group to increase retention of women and gender minorities in science. In addition, themes of environmental awareness and stewardship have been included into the undergraduate teaching curriculum at Portland State University.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Theresa Mccormick
